Review Text: Unfortunately  I find the litter on the beach and streets to be disgusting,  the majority of food is the same from place to place the riding of turtles is a big no and walking all over the corals to , I witnessed  every day , the whale watching trip chasing down whales in high powered boats en-mass is depressing also same in the nature reserve with elephants, the dogs need a culling and are crawling with allsorts of mites ect , this is not just hikk..this is all sri lanka..I've been all over coastal, and inland ect , I've travelled  all over the world and iam sick of reading how nice places are when frankly they're not , the country could be stunning if they cleaned it up .. went to Moz last year which is really poor and you don't get the levels of waste there ..such a shame ..but we met some nice locals saw some great sites sigariya the tea plantations ect, but overall such a letdown.. unfortunately  on my travels  this is becoming more and more.. this is a honest review I could write a book..but see for yourself .. I wish sri lankans all the best , but tidy up your country..

We spotted two right away, we watched them from a distance. You can't say that with other tourists who we saw being touched by force, and when he couldn't reach it, he needed to touch the turtle with his feet because he was eating from the corals. Tourists have a lot of fun with them, they touch them even though there are signs prohibiting it. Many tourists chase them headlong for photos and videos and forcefully touch them! It's quite sad.

There are many turtles, they are all huge. But there are also a lot of tourists, they bring them by the busload. We lived in a hotel directly opposite and went there in the mornings when no one was there yet. Locals scurry around on the beach and offer seaweed to feed the turtles; for a bag they ask from 100 to 1000 rupees (who has the nerve) In fact, these same algae grow literally 50 meters to the left of the beach (if you are facing the ocean) on the reef, but to get to them you need slippers - there are hedgehogs there and the corals cut your feet. I heard a story that a turtle slightly nipped a tourist by the leg - it’s strange, I haven’t noticed anything like that from turtles, they are not interested in anything except algae and they don’t attack people, so you can safely go there with your children and get to know them.

Our family of five, three adults and two children, spent time on and off at Hikkaduwa Beach while staying at Coral Sands Hotel between 25th to 28th December 2019.  We were there in the mornings and evenings, walking along the white sandy beach, swimming in the calm, clear blue waters or simply enjoying - sitting and lazing around. Diving and snorkelling gear are available for hire at many locations along the beach.  You can swim to the nearby colourful reef to watch and enjoy aquatic life - the many colourful fishes darting around as well as multi-coloured corals. If you are lucky you might come across a turtle too swimming in the waters.  Diving and snorkelling were a fabulous pastime for the many visitors frequenting the beach.  The calm shallow waters between the reef and the beach was ideal for a leisurely swim.  You can quench your thirst at the many juice bars along the beach. We enjoyed the walks along the lovely wide beach with its white sands and getting into the calm waters. The best time to enjoy Hikkaduwa beach is during the non-monsoonal period between November to March.

(Don't get suckered in to first class like we did, go second. See my other review) the streets are full of shops, bars, restaurants and some street food. We felt adventurous, so got some bbq fish and chicken from a stall at the beach car park. Wow! It's local, authentic, which means the fish is roughly chopped bbq'd sauced and spiced, as is the chicken and served in a cardboard dish. Lots of meat on the fish. Beautiful. Ask for spicy otherwise it will be mild. On to the beach. All manner of water sports on offer; scuba, snorkelling, glass bottom boat, surfing hire, lessons. We just swam and snorkelled in the warm water. At the southern end of the beach large sea turtles are found while wading in the shallow reef. We visited here quite a number of times during our week long stay In Hikkaduwa. Whilst is very beautiful, there is a VERY strong current so beware if you are planning a swim in the water. There were quite a few surfers and lots of places where you could hire snorkels, a boat trip, scuba lessons, etc. There were also a lot of people selling coconuts, pineapples and items of clothing. What I really like about Hikkaduwaa beach is that the beach itself has fabulous, beautiful, clear warm water, and lots of interesting things to see along the shoreline.  But along with that is that it’s a town big enough to feel like you are really living among the people and can break out of the tourist scene. Not so much a place to come for nightlife, or at least not that we’ve yet found now on day five, not really looking that hard, but definitely a very nice place to chill lax and observe some Sri Lankan culture. The train ride to get here from Colombo is exceedingly affordable and breathtaking as it runs right along the coast almost the entire way. Once here, it’s very easy to just jump on a passing bus to explore further down the coast line to places like Galle which offers more high-end shopping gorgeous views and lots of interesting history. In addition to tourism, fishing is a primary industry here and another fun thing to do is to go check out where the fishing boats bring their early morning catch and watch all of the locals making their choices. Don’t miss the surrounding neighborhoods and some of the treasures that they hold, small mom-and-pop businesses that offer great value and wonderful experiences. Also don’t miss a place sectioned off on the beach where baby turtles are kept safe beneath the sand until the eggs hatch and they are kept safe from predators until they are able to make their way down to the water. You can swim right up to the sea turtles but please please don’t touch. Touching may seem harmless but chemicals that we carry on our hands, like sunscreen, is very damaging to them. Locals are OK though with you feeding the turtles bits of seaweed which is a thrill to experience even vicariously. I have yet to do it but there is a living coral reef right up near the shore where you can snorkel.

Pristine beach compared to what we saw around Trincomalee. Nice, long strip to walk; good places to swim. Saw one place that offers surfing lessons. flanked by every different flavor or bar, restaurant, cafe. Many places where you can rent a chair and hang out all day.

We hired a glass bottom boat at coral sanctuaryand a life guard accompanied us, which took us to a deeper part of the sea where we jumped off with our life jackets on and it was breath taking, we spent about half hour there before we were taken closer to the shore and we could spend how much ever time we wanted. It was an amazing experience and safe for even non-swimmers. There are hundreds of varieties of fish that literally swim by you, unforgettable experience. Costed about 3000lkr per head. Only remember to stick to the areas he tells you to swim around to avoid the shallow areas where you could get injured by the sharp corals.

This is a lovely stretch of sandy beach with many restaurants and water sports options like snorkeling, diving, glass bottom boat rides etc. You can also take your own towel/mat and just relax on the beach or swim in the warm shallow waters (there's a reef less than 1km from shore that creates a relatively shallow pool of water and buffer from strong waves). It has lots of coconut trees so you can find a shady spot too if you want (not possible on some other beaches, which get too hot in the mid day sun).

We stayed on at The Coral roack by Bansei right on the beach front for a week.  We came for the snorkelling and it didnt dissappoint.  The snorkelling from the beach was great and the trip out to the rocks was also worth while. The beach is clean, safe and lively withour being overcrowded.  There are places to eat and drink all along the beach line.
The sandy beach is really clean and you can walk for an endless distance. Though you have waves you can normally swim in the sea. Pay attention to the current

Lovely beach with clear water and coral just off the shore, for a couple of £ you can hire snorkel and masks for a couple of hours and see plenty of fish. Apparently there are turtle towards the southern end of the beach as well. It was exceptionally busy when we were there, however it was both Christmas and Poya day, so a mass public holiday for Sri Lanka. That being said, it was friendly, very clean, and we managed to get a sun lounger outside of a bar with no problems. All in all a great spot.

It's a awesome beach with coral reef having beautiful fishes at one side and on the other side you can find big tortoises coming close to the shore for food. It's a awsm experience feeding the turtles. Shoreline is very short.
Gorgeous purple sunsets and orange sands. Free of trash, usually not too many people. Less vendors than other beach destinations like Boracay.
Tourism at its worst. Overcrowded, overpriced, no local atmosphere left. I hope what happened to Hikkaduwa doesn’t happen to other places we’ve visited and loved during our time in Sri Lanka.

If you want the surfing beach you need to be at the south end. There are a few reefs amongst the sand so need to pick a spot if swimming. Spent three days here then transferred to airport home for 7500 rupees ( three people and bags). It is fairly nice but Mirissa is all round a better spot. Stayed at The Bed which was good.

Went to hikkaduwa beach just round the corner from where the turtles come into land, had lovely lunch in sunny beach cafe but the surf schools either side were mid argument this resulted in them running around the beach screaming at each other carrying poles as weapons. About an hour later a fight did brake out 2 men onto one punching him in the face repeatedly and again they had the poles as weapons. So disgusting and dissapointing to see, inappropriate behaviour on a beach in front of families with children, will not be returning to that area of the beach. The photos show the name of surf schools

If you are into snorkelling and especially, if you are a nature/animal lover, you will be disappointed by people's behaviour in turtle point which i'll call "circus point". Some locals  are giving algaes to tourist so they can take pictures and videos. So, they end up being 3 or 4 people disturbing 1 or 2 turtles which sometimes can't even swim. And the 'funny" part is that the same local guys giving algaes, (for money of course and that is another story...) are asking them not to touch the turtles when feeding them. It's like what they do is not bad, the problem is just when you touch the animal.... If you just ignore this horror scene and go some meters further for snorkelling, you'll probably end up surrounded by boats with glass bottoms which are taking people who don't swim. So you can't enjoy it since   you have to be careful and to look up and around instead of looking down. So if i gave one out of 5, it's just for the beautiful fish that we couldn't even admire as we wanted.
The beach on the south side of cinnamon hotel is nice. Quite crowded and not as friendly occupants north of this spot!

Crowed, dirty and ugly beach. Unacceptable behaviour of tourists who are feeding, touching and moving the tortles who are living there. When people will learn that touching wild animals can kill them by transmit them diseases ?? You can find more beautiful beaches everywhere on the south coast of Sri Lanka.
Over crowded but it is coming into peak season.    A fair amount of pollution on the beach but good to see a life saver on patrol

We visited to see turtle point and feed the giants that come right up to you in the shallows  and you can hand feed with seaweed. Was an amazing experience to see a 150 year old green back turtle so close
I think it's batter beeches then all around because it is more quiet then all the beaches around. Nice and not so laudably restaurants

Very clean beach. They rake it everyday day. Bali needs to learn and thing or two from Sri Lanka. Can see green turtles and snorkel right off the beach here. Yes coral is dead but a lot of the world is but plenty of fish. Excellent
Stay within the coral area for a safe swim, and snorkel with beautiful fish , and curious turtles!   Go further up the beach, in the direction of Galle for surfing.
We stayed almost on the beaxh for a week. Beautiful long beach. Lovely for walking and meeting fellow beach walkers. a real gem to explore.

Save your time for Mirissa and Unawatuna. This place is dirty and the beach isn’t all that. The local area is quite scruffy too. There are two turtles fed by a local man as a tourist attraction and people surrounding them all day. There are not a lot of cafes or restaurants compared to the other beaches. Save your money for elsewhere.
A glorious stripe of sand and surf that seems to go on forever. We found it pristine clean and a joy to walk. Less so for swimming as the currents constantly shift. The surfers didn’t care!
If you are looking for a clean and nice beach, avoid this spot. If you like to bargain with service providers and like the crowd, then a must for a stop!

Its a lovely  beach, sea can be rough sometimes..big turtles come to the beach in the morning..sunsets are amazing..good place to hv a sea bath.. a walk on the soft golden sand..we enjoyed our stay there.
Nice beach, amazing sunsets. Clean of litter and lots of bars and restaurants to chose from! Lovely setting!
Lovely long beach which is good for surf beginners. Plenty of bars all along with a safe feeling about it. Food and drink readily available.

We stayed at the Hikka Tranz by Cinnamon .The hotel was a bit tired it really needs an up grade. It caters for a large group of tourists and I felt a bit overwhelmed with how many people stay at this hotel. No individual treatment .The beach was quite good with the  locals cashing in on taking you out to the rocks for snorkelling. Not much coral but some fish life.
Great beaches, plenty of good bars and restaurants. The curry bowl guest house is cheap and clean, worth considering as a base.
Quite, clean and easy access to see colourful fishes; Snorkeling or Glass boat. Numerous restaurants and bars are located along the entire stretch of the beach.

It's not the prettiest beach. There's some pretty good snorkelling at the northern end - we just wish we had taken flippers because the current was pushing us around. Lion fish, cuttlefish, reef sharks and turtles were the highlights. On the southern end there's a spot where all the tourists gather to feed one or two local turtles. It's a bit pushy shovy as people clamour for the best instagram shots. Would be a bit nicer if people wouldn't grab the turtles either. Other than that, usual beach things to do - bars, restaurants, surf, jetski, boat tours etc. Nice sunset too though.

This is a lovely beach that is totally spoilt by the awful way people treat the turtles. They are wild animals not there to be mounted and ridden, coerced onto the beach, or stalked through the water for hours (yes some individuals wouldn’t leave them alone for hours). It would be great if the initiative could be taken in the spots where they do appear frequently for signs to remind people of this. And for beach goers to educate themselves on how to treat wildlife appropriately. Enjoy the turtles from a respectful distance whether snorkelling or paddling.. More about the beach: As is often in Sri Lanka the waves are rough, something to bear in mind if you have little ones. But they are fine if you’re a fairly good swimmer. You can find some good spots for sunbathing at points along the beach. There are the occasional littered areas in between. We walked home as the sun was going down to a nice sunset and impressive lightning on the horizon. As the beach isn’t one long strip it makes an interesting walk round all the bends. We enjoyed ourselves.

Great beach, just over two hours from Colombo airport. Great place for diving, snorkelling, surfing and generally chilling out. Stays are comfortable, people are warm and friendly and the seafood is exceptional.

I spent eight Wonderful days Walking, Sunbathing, Boggie Boarding and Swimming at Hikkaduwa Beach!! The endless miles of mostly very clean Golden sand beaches and a very Powerful Crashing Ocean surf!! Great beach bars for miles, so many choices!! The Main Reef Guesthouse and restaurant is a wonderful establishment which is where I stayed while in Hikkaduwa. The Chill Space Beach Bar just a few hundred feet away from the Main Reef has an Exciting Saturday night Beach Party with Dancing and disco!! Cheers!! James B. Oregon USA

We stayed near Hikkaduwa beach for a month and this was our sunset point almost everyday and each day it would be better than before! Beach right behind Hikkaduwa trans hotel has few huge turtles visiting every day and one of them is named Rosy by the local guides. If you walk on the beach from here towards north, you can find a reef on the beach at low tide. It’s safe and easy to swim even for beginners!

Theres not alot of sand here, not much of a beach at all. Hotels are practically built right up to the waters edge with only 2 or 3 metres of sand inbetween. The beach is also full of rubbish and derbis which no one seems to take responsibility for. I'm not sure about the rest of the year but in October its also fairly impossible to swim in the sea here as the sea is so rough and the currents are too strong. Also, touts try selling you everything from massages, coconuts, boat trips, blankets, sight seeing tours, wooden figurines, swimming with turtles....you name it! Not relaxing at all.
A beautiful beach with golden soft sand, the sea was crystal clear and the kids had a lovely time. A few lovely seafood restaurants with live catch along the way to choose from.

We spend there 3 days where really the best in our Sri Lanka trip. People there are very friendly and there are many lodges and restaurant on the beach. Every night there is a party in one of these restaurants where everyone from the hotels around come. in the morning it is very nice to surf on that beach and I would just say it was really the best city we stayed in while in Sri Lanka

Super clean..quite and lovely sand beach to relax .. lot of shopping near by and surfing is fun here .. there is a company hikkasurf.com Name of the trainer -Uppal who give surfing lessons.. there are lot of restaurants near by to pickup some thing from the restaurant and get a beer from a wine shop and sit on the beach to relax ..

NIce coral beach although I must say that a lot of the coral has now been bleached due to the warming of the sea. However, if you come to the beach in the morning there are a lot of sea turtles that come to the beach to eat plankton. There are a few beach boys who will give you seaweed and walk with you into the sea to feed the turtles

Its a nice beach just next to the main road. You can enjoy the sunset with a drink at any bar which are located next to the beach. Early morning you can see the big turtle which come near Hikka Tranz Hotel.

What a lovely spot this is. Watching all of the fishing boats, men fishing on poles and would be surfers plying their new activity love was a nice break after a long car drive. Recommend this as a nice stop over Expertly co-ordinated by Blue Lanka tours
Close to hotels and restaurants. Clear water beach gold sand. Can get fresh drinks alcohol at the beach. Very relaxing

We really wanted to snorkel and surf when we got to Hikkaduwa but unfortunately we were told the coral reef has been destroyed so the snorkeling isn't brilliant - we nearly decided to go anyway but after 1 day of seeing people go in to the sea with their snorkel and come out 10 minutes later we decided not to bother. The beach itself is nice and you can walk along and go into restaurants and bars. We also wanted to surf - but we were near the corner of the beach (stayed in Hikka Trans by Cinnamon) and there were 2 different wave patterns so it wasn't brilliant for surfing either.... this could be just where we were though and the time of year!! The sunsets however from this side were fantastic!!!!
The beach is great , turtles seen in the coral seas. Snorkelling was a good experience.Many deep sea diving activities.
A lovely stretch of beach with some evidence of tsunami still present. Great photography opportunties

I am traveling on my own, and I have to say that it was quite relaxing to find a sand beach where I could walk, but water was quite scary to jump. I highly recommend Hikkaduwa beach If you come to the south, but as a person who looks for exploring cultures, I have to say that I found this spot too touristic.
Booking a hotel or guest house in Hikkaduwa can be an excellent option. Bars, restaurants, shops and snorkeling and nice beach. From there, you can visit others beaches like Bentota or Mirissa

Having walked down beautiful Adam’s Peak, been mesmerized by the scenery in Ella, soaked in the ambience of Tangalle and Mirissa, Hikkaduwa was not only a huge disappointment, but also felt dreadfully unsafe. Whilst Tangalle and Mirissa were lined with the flora and fauna of Sri Lanka, there were a few coconut trees in Hikkaduwa, but mostly the view is of delapidated, eery, empty hotels. Unlike elsewhere where you could easily get delicious Sri Lankan food for a good price, this place was full of naff restaurants serving expensive Western food, and poor quality at that. Perhaps the most difficult thing is the large groups of local men just wandering around gawking at tourists and in particular hassling women. Having travelled lots of the South for two weeks we expected some people to peddle their wares, but this was constant and at times quite aggressive. At one point whilst I was trying to read my book I had to tell somebody to back away because he was pestering so much. Hardly relaxing. In terms of the tourist population, whilst in other places it was full of backpackers travelling around, here it was mostly what seemed to be people on package deals just here for the beach. Unfortunately, it did give it quite a chavvy vibe and felt somewhat cheap but not cheerful, and not actually even cheap! *Perhaps most distressing was the ‘turtle watching’* Basically, a group of Sri Lankan guys encourage large sea turtles onto the shore (possibly captured and brought in) and feed them seaweed to keep them close. If tourists were to feed them seaweed they have to pay a fee. I gather if they dont pay they get quite intimidating. These tourists then go up to these beautiful creatures and distress them by petting them and taking pictures with them. It really is heartwrenching to see, and astounding how oblivious so many tourists are to how awful this practice is. Sri Lanka has so much beauty and excitement to offer - thank goodness I only spent one day here as it doesn’t show you how great Sri Lanka is. I would discourage anyone from visiting this place.

We went to the beach to watch sea turtles and were disgusted by the experience. We went there early morning, to find a group of 4 Sri Lankan men very aggressively asking for money for them to go and get the turtles out of the sea. We stayed there about an hour and this is how it works: those men stay on the beach and ask for money, they make sure you can’t go too close to the water and if a sea turtle tries to come on the beach, they scare it away back to the water to make sure you don’t see it until you pay. One of them had a knuckle duster and showed it to a tourist that was trying to find turtles with some seaweeds. A couple of tourists paid to see one, they took them in the water to make sure the rest of us would not see anything from the beach. The sea was rough and it looked like the couple did not know how to swim and was very uncomfortable, they apparently managed to get a turtle come and say hi to them for 10 sec and that was it. They also tricked some other tourists for paying 200 roupies, and once the turtle was approaching, they asked 2000 roupies. When the tourists said no, that was not the price, then they scared the turtle back to the water. Please do not go and do not pay as it entertains their business!!!

I chose a destination reachable by car from the capital's airport because I had only few vacation days for the Qingming Festival. The beach area turned out to be amazingly unspoiled, sea turtles, for example, were visible upon wading from the shore.Excellent wide sand beaches and impressive surfing conditions added tremendously to the value. I also enjoyed scuba diving. Visitors were predominately Europeans. Would come again !
One of the best surfspots i have bin to! Nice people, warm water and good breaks! Whene you are a surfer you must visit this village.

This is the place if you want to see turtles. They are fed seaweed and come really close. Hikkaduwa Beach is located in the center of Hikkaduwa and is nice in the summer when the waves are really high, as it has a wavebraker. Otherwise is the beach not that big but is connected to Narigama Beach where you can walk and surf.
we always love Hikka beach, almost full with Hotels, high tourism area, any tourist who visits sri lanka should go there,
Had a lovely visit during the night time to this beach. It is very beautiful and peaceful, I would love to visit again during the day time.

This beach is lovely, nice soft sand and warm water. We were unlucky as on one of the days a group of Sri Lankan youths were harassing a young white girl. Her partner came from the water to help. A Sri Lankan man stepped in then they started fighting with wood !! It kind of put is off from staying on the beach. However we were just unlucky

Ive been to Hikka a few times now and I love it there. the beaches are lush, real long sandy beaches with a range of surf options from beginner right up to top level. when theres no surf theres a reef right off the main beach where you can see lots of fish and turtles from. the waters real clear here and warm. if youre going for nightlife this is the place to be, theres pretty much a party in a different club every night and the parties get loose. particularly over new years and xmas when the parties are massive. theres also lots of shops and stuff to have a look at to entertain yourself and theres plenty other things to visit like the turtle conservation place and the elephant orphanage isnt too far away hikkaduwa is an epic place but is quite busy with a fairly loud main road with traffic most the night
Had an amazing stay. The rooms are decorated with so much detail and love the idea of them all having their own theme. All the staff were lovely, deffinetly recommend.
If you want to create memories and have a great time then get yourself down to this beach.... it’s clean and the water is warm. Plenty of cold bears and places to eat at the beach huts.

Very nice beach with cool vibe, clear waters, a lot of cafes to chill at, all within a walking distance one to another... the sun is tricky , you definitely need to use sun protection. My wife and I were already tanned so we thought we will not get burned and boy were we wrong!
We visited Hikkaduwa in July and there were barely people at the beach; sea was rough with waves; found out that it was kind of out-of season.
Lovely beach, very clean beautiful walk along the whole beach, watching the waves, also catching a couple of people surfing.

If you go here in the wrong season, it's a terrible place. The beach is windy and the water murky. But I'm sure it's beautiful when the season is right. But to be safer with the weather I would just go a bit further south to Unawatuna....
The back is Nice but rough. To man boats sufers and rude local.. The restaurants around play to much loude music

Reviewer Name: Sri Lanka Holiday Homes And Tours
Review Text: Hikkaduwa is the best beach for spend your vacation period. Because the beach is very clean and it is a white sand beach. You can do lot of things in hikkaduwa. they are, snorkeling, diving, surfing, see the coral reefs and turtles. Not only that you can get another lot of experiences outside the beach. They are, hikkaduwa mangrove safari and fish therapy, visit the buddhist temples, visit turtle hatchery, get ayurvedic treatments and spa, enjoy the nightlife. So don't forget to enjoy with hikka in your sri lankan tour....!!!

This is a beautiful beach. Can get crowded sometimes. Turtles turn up on the shore near Hikka Tranz because people keep on feeding them. You may find beautiful corals standing up on the beach. What more can you ask for!

Hikkaduwa was a huge disappointment. The ocean was very, very rough and we could not even enter the water in some areas.  We visited at the end of July - it is apparently much calmer after December.  The sand is not fine and powdery and there was garbage strewn about.  Peddlers were plentiful but mainly tolerable; it was the random men who hang around the beach who were very annoying. Hikkaduwa town is dirty, noisy, and chaotic.  Walking down the 'sidewalk' or crossing the road is downright dangerous - the buses and other vehicles fly by pedestrians and each other at fairly high speeds in tight quarters.  I am surprised there aren't more accidents.  The fumes and pollution from vehicles is overwhelming.  Proprietors are aggressive.  It seems like everyone is trying to get something from you or sell something to you.  It's exhausting. I am not sure what tourists see in this place - beauty must really be in the eye of the beholder.

This is a lovely beach to stroll, swim or snorkel. Plenty of outfitters are waiting to guide you, either by paddling out to the reef or swimming with you near the shore. The reef was okay, and getting paddled out there in the long canoe was cool, but really, the fish were better near shore. unfortunately, the coral was destroyed in the tsunami, but there are still fish. We got up-close and personal with two large turtles near shore. It you have even a bit of snorkelling experience, just rent the fins and mask and enjoy the shoreline. People keep dumping bread in the ocean to attract them and they are plentiful, if not too varied.

The beach is pretty nice, but there’s not a lot of space to lay down and enjoy the weather. The sea is very rough in August and it’s not very safe to swim. There are also a lot of locals who try to get you on one of those boats with a glass bottom and they won’t stop pushing you until you walk away. Very annoying and not relaxing at all. There are a few reasonably priced restaurants near the coast that are nice.

This beach is beautiful, quite a big one and gives amazing views with clear clean water and also lots of water animals towards the other end of the beach. It started raining heavily when I went here with my friends and we had the best fun bathing in the beach with rains on our head :) there are some cool cafes and bars having sunbeds all over where you can enjoy good food and view. Also the beach has amazing beach resorts and you can grab a good deal to stay in any one of them , that was the most memorable part of my entire trip.

I loved this beach for July as we stayed at coral seas... If you go left towards the point you can feed turtles in the mornings.  One local guy takes care of them and protects them from tourist that don't treat them with respect... Please give him a tip, he didn't ask for one but after what I saw and how much he loves them he deserves a hefty tip. This beach between coral seas hotel and the point has the best sand beach with gentle waves in July at least.  Also a lifeguard on duty and shade trees to sit under. This was our 3rd beach as we started in mirissa, I loved each city for a different reason, this one was my favorite beach for swimming.    Mirissa for food, weligama for surfing.

We went here for a evening to enjoy the sunset and snockling. It was very disappointing as the guys who were running the snockling tours were very unprofessional, they were drinking one of the instructor even misbehaved with girls. There were no cost guard or any kind of security. I will suggest to not do any water activity here with local instructors. Beach is good but rest in worst. There are many other better option in Srilanka so try and avoid this if you can.

There is a vast expanse of beach, ideal for a sea bath. Large turtles can be seen in the morning, who wade in to the shallow areas of the sea. You can feed them sea weed and touch and take photographs.
The beach is broad which make it possible to relax for several hours at the beach enjoying the ocean. The beach is not suitable for surfing since the waves breaks very close to shore
Beach seemed relatively clean and although it was pretty rough, was in good condition. There seemed to be some more secluded beaches further north, but the tide seemed to come in pretty high.

We were out o season so it was quiet. From the various signs, the Russians have found here. The beach is scenic but plastic debris everywhere. The beach is famous for its turtles. A local man sidled up to us keen to show us the turtles. He had a younger companion who entered the sea to entice a turtle to me using seaweed - and it worked - to some extent and I did catch a glimpse of a large turtle close by. Of course these gentlemen wanted to be paid for their time and effort and help the local community. A further (persistent)  offer to sample the local Aloe Vera was declined. The beach has many watering holes and we enjoyed some calamari and beer at the end of the morning.

The coral reef glass boat ride was an ad-hoc proposal by our local guide as a short activity during our Galle-to-Bentota ride. June is not the best season for sailing far out to areas of better diversity because of the current but we were able to see quite a good variety of marine life including sea turtle on the shallower reef side. There are a few people snorkelling so you can probably see the same things without paying for the ride. However note the sea can get quite choppy, combine that with shallow waters and rocky bottoms, a boat ride is not a bad option if you are interested to see the reef.

This was a real eye opener with signs in Russian and Russian menu's but no hassle and clean beach (surprised local Tourist Board/Council  still do not pick up the plastic which is surprising as many other beaches have tractor and litter plastic pickers to preserve the major tourist attraction. Great sunsets and good for jogging along the beach when tide is out.

One of the Surf and beach highlights of S/L. Come in the dry non monsoon offshore season for best surf. Great coral reef breaks but dangerous for learners. Stay near the shore otherwise. Great coral snorkling. Plenty of accommodation and restaurants along the parade. Beauty personified. For an extra experience hire a scooter and go inland to visit the Moon stone quarries. Mind blowing.
Have a stop and enjoy the view. Marvelous beach and loads of stores around for shopping and massage. Highly recommended :)
One of the best beaches in Sri Lanka if you have to do snorkelling. Has quiet a few rocks in the beach so have to be careful.

hikkaduwa beach is very clean beach with relaxing and safe place to spend some quality time. lot of good restaurant and bar and around , local people are very helpful and friendley. had great time with my friends
Great beach with good options for families and kids. Surfing options available and close to all hotels and resorts

You cannot miss this beach as they are so nice and clean.. except few parts where there are alot of people. Otherwise if you are staying in any guest house, you will be able to experience your own private beach front.
Excellent beach with good snorkeling right off the beach and giant sea turtles swimming right up to the shore. Excellent swimming area. Good restaurant options on the edge of the beach.

For best experience- find the hotels with entrance from the Hikkaduwa-Galle main road and the other end is facing the beach. A cool and calm place with a chilled beer watching the waves will make your day!!

On the south of the island, in places like Unawatuna and Hikkaduwa, lie the white sands of the Indian Ocean beaches. A far cry from the green jungles and tea plantations on the mountains. However, all you have to do is take a look around, and if the beach is quiet, it’s easy to imagine yourself as a deserted sailor from centuries ago washing onto an uninhabited island. Sitting on the shoreline, listening to the waves lap up the beach, watching the sky go from yellow, to red, to black, is an extremely relaxing way to end the day.
This is a must on your travels in sri lanka. The beaches around area are beautiful with lots of swimming snorkelling and surfing to be done. Plus swimming with giant turtles.

Our Hotel had entrances directly onto the beach so we took regular strolls along it as well as swam / snorkelled from it. It is a public beach (why not), and there are plenty of people around but it is not unpleasantly crowded.and the food / beverage shacks etc add to the ambience. Yes there are boat vendors etc along the shore, but they generally accept a polite no, and don't hassle you further. We especially liked the area to the North, where most of the locals went (en masse), to enjoy themselves, and seeing them happy, made us happy too. Going into the sea from this beach is very easy and no rubber footwear required, Warning, be vigilant of the many small tourist boats that operate in a most cavalier way in the same area. I snorkelled out lots of times, wearing bright flourescent gear. However, I had to stop many times, and shout loudly at the boat crew, to make them aware of my presence.( they were too busy amusing their customers by doing fast 'doughnuts' in the water and throwing bread over for the fish) This was very unsafe practice and dangerous to swimmers.. The authorities, should segregate the boats from swimmers by roped off areas with marker buoys, as they are in many other parts of the world. It is also  a great shame to see ignorant people feeding the fish bread etc and feeding / stroking the turtles.too. Titillating as it may be for you, please stop and think, as you are changing the diet and behaviour of the marine life. Thereby, you are quite literally killing them. Maybe some informative notices need to go up along the beach ( and make sure they are in written in the Russian language too ). We still love the place, and would not hesitate to return here at any time.

The beach is nice, and within yards you can see lots of tropical fish if you can snorkel. You don't need anyone's help to see the fish, or for them to be fed. So beware of touts offering trips in glass bottom boats and snorkelling assistance. We got conned because it was our first day in SL. The glass boat was rubbish, you cannot see much through the old glass and there are very few fish in the marine sanctuary part anyway. Then we were kitted out with life jackets and snorkelling gear and lead to the shallow part where locals were playing in the water. There were lots of fish here, but there was no reason to pay someone to see this. Better to bring your own snorkel and enjoy. The rains came and the water became unclear so we did not see the turtles even though we went to the other side of the beach. The guy who was supposed to act as our paid life guard was sitting bored while my kids were in the water  - they were not in any danger but I realised he had oversold his credentials. As others have said, the fish and turtles do not belong to locals, so take your own bread to feed them and avoid the useless operators who are trying to hassle and exploit visitors.

I would not recommend swimming here because the high waves but I saw some people swimming and surfing - remember to duck under the wave if you do. There are restaurants and bars that are spread, which worked for us very well because we were only walking on the beach. The beach is very long so it is suitable for a walk.

The area is lovely and it is great to walk along the beach. However, the long stretch where the restaurants and bars are located, as well as hotels with sun lounges. Is extremely dangerous and unsafe for swimming. The beach around the point has a lot of small rocks under foot, but is very safe for swimming and especially good for children under the watchful of eye adults!
One of my fav beaches. Very beautiful. The waves can be very big though, so it’s not safe for small kids. The main bit near Citron hotel is calmer.

It is more coral and is a little rockier, but it also has sea turtles who will swim in throughout the day.   My kids each had a chance to put on a mask and swim along side the gentle creatures.  It was an amazing experience.  One thing, PLEASE DO NOT TOUCH THE TURTLES.  They are wild animals and this can harm them.   There was a wonderful local man who spent his day reminding tourist it is not okay to touch the turtles. There were lots of opportunities for snorkeling and diving with a shop on site to rent equipment.  The beach was also clean and quiet - great for reading watching the waves, or taking a nap. There are also fruit salesman on the beach.  It sounds  silly, but it was fun to drink from a coconut and eat fresh pineapple on the beach.  We bartered the price down to about 800 rupies - be ready to do that :)

This was really a bit of a rip off. With most of the hotels and restaurants jealously commanding their own strip of beach in Hikkaduwa, there are only few places where you can gain free access to the beach. When you do find an access you usually find a fleet of little glass bottomed motor boats waiting to take you for a spin over what remains of the Hikkaduwa coral reef. We took a short 15 minute trip to the edge of the shallow coral reef and although the boat trip was regulated and tickets issued, you may consider it overpriced. The coral reef is very close to the shore and on our trip we were fortunate to see a large turtle as well as some large fish. The coral reef however, is a natural disaster, because much of the coral is dead, due to bleaching in 1998. Damage to the reef is also due to fishing and by boats There are a few signs of it regenerating but it will be many, many years before, if ever, it will return to its former glory. We realized afterwards that the little glass bottomed boat that we used was a contributor to the damage on the reef. The best way of seeing the reef is by snorkeling and you can be guided to the best spots. But be careful of the little glass bottomed boats.

After spending a few days in Negombo our overall impression of Sri Lanka was not great and we were getting a bit frustrated and bored. We decided to take a 2.5 hour cab ride down to Hikkaduwa beach after getting recommendations from locals and other travellers. We stopped by the Turtle Sanctuary which was very cool. We had been told that it was possible to spot turtles in the sea further down Hikkaduwa beach, but that we had to be very lucky to do so - especially if we arrived later in the day. We arrive to Hikkaduwa beach around 10-11am. It was raining as we made our way down to the shore but as soon as we got there we already saw a handful of people in the water, looking at a massive turtle. After having a look from the beach we rented a mask and snorkel for 500LKR each and got in the water. We were amazed! 4-5 massive turtles were calmly swimming around us - the biggest one probably around 1.5m long! Definitely one of the most amazing experiences I’ve ever had. I think the fact that it was raining made a big difference. We were told that the turtles don’t like sunlight and there was also less people swimming.

Once you get into Hikkaduwa beach you will find fine golden sand, clear water, good wave action, snorkeling and diving opportunities and beautiful views. There is a little bit of a litter problem but it could easily be rectified if someone took responsibility for clearing it regularly. It’s not at an offensive level at present but is noticeable. The biggest problem I found with this beach is it is so difficult to access. We dropped in to visit on our train trip to Galle. After leaving Hikkaduwa train station we headed to the Galle - Colombo main road along the beach. There we encountered the fishing harbour ( no access to beach) abutting strip shops and continuous cement block walls that meant we had to walk at least 800 m before we could find a lane thru to the beach. Although it’s a tourist town Hikkaduwa is not pedestrian friendly - tuktuks, vans and trucks park over narrow footpaths and make angry gestures or toot horns at pedestrians trying to walk along the shopping strip to shop or get to the beach. Pedestrians are made to feel that they are the lowest priority which is the opposite to most western countries, so it takes some getting used to. Some of the properties along the beach encroach too far onto the beach, leaving less beach for swimmers to set up camp for the day. A lot of businesses that back onto the beach at the port / city end do not open onto the beach and are aesthetically ugly. If the local traders wish to appeal more to tourists then they may need to rethink zoning for businesses along the beach and improve access to the beach. I guess the concrete block wall may be intended as a barrier to flooding but perhaps a stairway or pedestrian bridges could improve beach access. Until access improves I would rate Unawatuna as the best close proximity  beach for tourists who are staying in Galle I think Hikkaduwa could be a highly rated beach for tourists, with a few improvements to better accomodate them. I’m saying this from the perspective that I think tourism is an important economic driver and employment focus for this town.

We stayed in Hikkaduwa for 3 nights, it was amazing. The beach is calm, water is warm, and you can enjoy a swim. The locals are friendly, sellers wandering the beach do not harass you. A simple ‘no thank you’ will suffice. Towards the Hikka Tranz hotel end of the beach, you get to swim with the turtles. The turtles do not mind the people but tends to get over crowded. For quieter time with the turtles, go visit them in the morning, take few sea plants with you to feed them. You will get great pictures. You can snorkel or swim with them too. To view the corals, you will need to take the boat out into the sea, it is about 10-15 minutes boat ride. Fish comes up right on the beaches. A great place for who are not yet able to snorkel and dive. It is wonderful to see various type of fishes swimming along with you. Along the beach, there are lot of restaurants with various price ranges. All of them seems to be on higher end. Do not forget to put on sun screen, you will get sun burnt very easily. The beach area does not have public shower or restroom. You will need to use your hotel facilities.

Very noisy being next to busy main road and could do with a clean up in places. Good swimming and to walk along. You will find turtles close to shore.
One of best beach I ever Visited, with beautiful view and um So lucky to visit here. Most of foreigners are love to visit here.
Great place to stay. Such friendly local and a real village vibe while still having all you could what from Western point of view. Some good surf, excellent snorkelling and wildlife. Love this place!

Hikkaduwa was the last stop on our four weeks travel in Sri Lanka. Compared to Trincomalee mirissa arugam bay, tangalle, kalpitiya Habarana it was vey touristy but also "very" clean. We kind of enjoyed part of it, because we could do a bit of shopping and chose different kind of food after have been pretty stuck with rice and curry. Recommend to stay a little away from the Main Street (villa Dineha is great) because of the noisy and smelly traffic. The beach is nice and clean. Good for surfing and bodyboarding or just playing in the waves. Lot of beach chairs. The snorkeling on the west end of the beach is fun, lots of fish, but the coral is 90 % dead but what is still alive gives a hint of what was once there.

We stayed at a hotel on the beach and had a great time walking up and down it during the day and evening. There are lots of food choices with drinks and many friendly people! The ocean is rocky in some spots, sandy in others and is a great place to surf and scuba. All in all an obvious MUST DO while in Hikkaduwa.
One of the best beaches I've been in Sri Lanka. If you are lucky you might even see a giant sea turtle. Loads to see and do.
This beach is not as touristy as Unawatuna. It is also smaller but good waves and plenty of avtivities. It is a close walk to shops and restaurants.

Hikkaduwa beach is good for surfers as the waves are quite big. Not good for small children. The beach is long, and at one place there is a quite dead coral reef. Nice fish though. At the north end of the beach where there are no hotels, we saw a sea turtle! It was eating algae off a big rock in the water. Amazing!
Wonderful beach with lots of comfortable sun beds and shade. Many restaurants and bars to pick from depending on taste! Much less busy and built up compared to mirissa and Unawatuna.

We came to this beach primarily because of the coral reefs so we went on a glass boat trip and afterwards on snorkeling. The reef is largely damaged due to tsunami, but the fishes around it are amazing. We even so two giant turtles swimming around. To the left of the reef is a large sandy beach with no rocks, just sand and we went there to swim. However the waves were crazy and unpredictable, and the sea current very strong. Beside the fact that the waves had beaten us badly in one moment the current dragged me into deep. I started panicking a bit, but thank God one surfer noticed me and came to rescue. I definitely wouldn't suggest this beach to bad swimmers or families with small children.

We went here just to see the turtles. The beach itself is small, crowded, too many locals selling things. feel as if everyone is on top of one another. There is a area where the turtles swim close to the shore where many people snorkel. We were lucky to see a few turtles swimming , but the waves were rough that days and the turtles apparently do not ike that so they stay away. Besides seeing the turtles briefly, there is no reason to come to this beach.
This is a dead coral beach and nothing so great. You can totally avoid it, we stayed at hikka tranz and the beach nearby was super crowded and not so great.
Hikkaduwa beach can get very crowded as it’s super touristic but perfect for surfing and some parts for swimming. Beautiful sunsets

Beautiful Long Beach covered by palms, no crowds! There are restaurants and beach bars with large choices of food, drinks, ice cream. Sea is quite wild, waves great for 🏄😉. Book hotel with view on beach and with pool. We loved it here!
They have corals very close to the beach and the beach is quite clean. Not too many vendors haggling you so it was quite good. We saw lot of fish very close to the sea

The sea was warm and fairly calm. A black river runs into the sea so I fear it's not that hygienic, saw strange things floating in the water e.g. A doormat. The beach has lovely soft sand though. Round the corner from the river was a very clear section of sea where people were snorkelling. The beach there was a bit pebbly. I would go there again but Mirissa is much nicer and wins hands down.

The beach itself is very narrow, there are a lot of restaurants/hotels/diving shops here that eat out the space. Also a lot of boats in the water and on land, sometimes it just smells like burnt petrol. The place is nice if you like scuba diving, very convenient. Also the sand is fine and goldish.
We stay here for 5 Nights. It is a very nice Place with Party, Music, beachbars and a lot of Surfers. You can Not good swim there, the Waves are big and powerful.
Beautiful beach with great snorkling opportunities! The first day on the beach we even saw four large seaturtles on the beach below the Hikka Tranz Hotel.
Not a surfer myself it's a great beach to grab a drink or food from a plethora of places whilst watching surfers conquer some great waves.
Very beautiful white beach. In April there is nice weather. I recommend to stay in Hikka Tranz Hotel, one of the best hotel with good service, good food and kind staff.
This is a great beach by all means, but the waves are fairly large; generating strong rip currents. Several people being rescued every day, no consistent warnings given to the public.
We didn’t spend awhile there and we had a d3licious lunch on the beach. Nice but not a highlight.Backpakers would like the surfing and cheap lodging on the beach.

The beach in Hikkaduwa is nice and is very good too walk because of its length. If you like wawes its the right place, but it was difficult to get in and out of the water for me as an middle aged women 😉

Whats good The innocent looking beach has treasures that one can't fathom in a week. From fishes in knee deep water to scuba tours, Hikkaduwa offers everything to everyone - a quintessential beachtown that makes you laydown and relax. Whats not good A tourist helpdesk will help. What to do Snorkel. Scuba dive. Lie down. Watch the sunset. Read a book. Enjoy food in seaside restaurant or Pizza hut right across the street.
we were very fortunate that we saw 5 large turtles on the hikkaduwa beach infront of cinnamon tranz ..... experience of a life time

Amazing place with wonderful food and people. The beaches were beautiful with lots of beach front dining available. Our hotel was right on the beach along the main road. I loved the chefs hats they had, so they went home to their village and had their aunt make me some for my chef at work in Australia. Recommend highly.
Great Beach not that commercial Really good to make a Walk at  the beach is cool because allways changing the style ...............................
it's a wow experience to all... my kids love the beach and cant take them from the water... they love the beach

Hikkaduwa beach is very beautiful and not too crowded with loud bars, theres just enough. Theres enough activities to do , like feeding the giant turtles and rescuing small ones, snorkeling, scuba diving, surfing etc, but the best quality is that it is a clean beach.
Nice place to chill and have fun lots of shops, restaurant, bars, ayurvedic centers beautiful long beach offering snorkelling and surf.
Beach was okay, far nicer ones in other places in Sri Lanka! Not the cleanest either with quite a few dogs running around.

We spent the last days here and liked it a lot. In comparison to Bentota, Unawatuna and Mirissa the best beach strip. It is touristic and maybe soon their will be too many Russians, but at this time it was ok. The city has good infrastructure with shops, restaurants, markets and offers everything you need. The beaches on the south part 400 meters south from Hikka Tranz Hotel ist the best part with lots of sunbeds and you can watch the surfers. In the northern part the wastewater from all the hotels goes to the ocean :( The only thing is the crazy busy street, you have to pass it carefully. The tourist board should slow down the traffic.
I loved this place. Sri Lanka as a whole is amazing and this was a great place to top it all off. Highly recommend this place.
This beach is beautiful! But also very busy with tourists. If that's what you like you'll love it but it was a but touristy and prices a bit inflated for us as students
Nice beach but not so big. Dining/ drinking with your feet i  the sand. Lot of places to eat drink and party. Quit places but also more crowded.

Went there by taking the train which was a scenic journey of 2 hours with the train chugging along while hugging the coastline. Amazing view of the beaches all the way to the Hikkaduwa beach. The place we went to was a diving school with PADI certified divers. Me and my son went diving with them and the experience was awesome. Though the reefs are not in good condition but the sea life is aplenty. The dive and the instructions takes around three hours and we were tired. The Chilled beer and the spicy seafood was perfect for the setting sun. We went ahead to Galle to visit the Dutch Fort....
Im not really a swimmer in the ocean in the first place, but the sea is pretty rough. Lovely beach and plenty of bars/restaurants all up and down

Very easy Gow style beach with lots of bars/guesthouses/restaurants next to each other packed. Surf ok but much better in the south. Perfect to relax after heavy travels before heading to south or center!
Hikkaduwa is one of the best beaches I have ever gone... Though there was the cyclone issue when I was there.. The climate was wonderful.. We had a great time there at the beach...

Nice beach with a lot of restaurants and surf shops. Not very wide but long enough for a nice walk. Fairly clean, friendly dogs and a reef at one end where the snorkling is supposed to be good (didn't snorkle so don't know).
We really loved Hikkaduwa, perfect place to chill out for a few days, we did our padi open water there as well

I am not a big fan of touristy beaches but Hikka is a must do. Lively shops, some good restaurants. Do not forget to visit one of the Tsunami mueseums (I particularly liked the simple and touching museum on the South side (free donation). I also APPRECIATE VERY much that visitors cannot  walk in swimsuits in the village main street anymore. When I first saw that years ago I was shocked as this is not Benidorm, visitors should adjust a bit to local culture... You will need RC here, the coast is really hot!
Great beach and the water was so warm. There’s lots of water activities and I was able to go surfing all day for 10$. Lots of places to eat and the beach wasn’t too busy which was good.

During off-season, this beach is a gem as it is never crowded, has great sand and clean water with sufficient waves to have fun (careful of undercurrents), and plenty of restaurants and bars to replenish and relax. Early morning fishing and evening strolls topped with splendid Indian Ocean sunsets provide for a truly magnificent experience.
